# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter dataframe to only include Audi A4 and A4 Quattro models
    df_audi = df_cars[df_cars.manufacturer .== "Audi", :]
    df_audi = filter(row -> (row.model == "A4" || row.model == "A4 quattro"), df_audi)
    
    # Create a new column indicating whether the car is an Audi A4 or A4 Quattro
    df_audi[:audi_a4_type] .= true
    return df_audi
end
```

This function first filters the `df_cars` DataFrame to include only rows where the manufacturer is "Audi". Then it applies a filter to this subset to include only cars with model name "A4" or "A4 quattro". Finally, it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` and sets all values in that column to `true`. The resulting DataFrame is returned at the end of the function.
